content.text1: There were 220,000 acres of oyster reefs.
content.text2: Whales, dolphins, seals, seahorses, herring, striped bass, and hundreds of other species in the Harbor enjoy the benefits of the oyster reefs.
content.text3: This ecosystem sustained the local Lenape people for generations.
content.text4: At this point in time, New York Harbor was one of the most diverse and dynamic environments on the planet.

content.text1: New Yorkers are eating oysters, and lots of them.
content.text2: This high demand leads to a conservation law that bans harvesting from NYC oyster reefs.
content.text3: This allows the wild oyster population to replenish itself.
content.text4: But this legislation only lasted till 1807.

content.text1: In 1833, Sandy Ground was founded on Staten Island by free African Americans after slavery was abolished in New York.
content.text2: Skilled Black oystermen migrated from Maryland, bringing expertise in oyster harvesting.
content.text3: They built thriving businesses, making Sandy Ground one of the oldest continuously settled Black communities in the U.S.
content.text4: The oyster trade became central to both community prosperity and New York’s food culture.

content.text1: By the mid-1800s, oyster beds were being overharvested to meet high demand.
content.text2: At the same time, New York’s new Combined Sewer Overflow (CSO) system dumped raw sewage into the harbor. CSO is still in place today.
content.text3: Pollution and overfishing left New York Harbor nearly lifeless by 1900.
content.text4: The once-thriving ecosystem became known for filth and disease.

content.text1: The last commercial oyster bed in New York closed in 1927.
content.text2: In 1972, the Clean Water Act banned the dumping of untreated sewage into U.S. waters.
content.text3: Over time, water quality in New York Harbor began to improve.
content.text4: Oysters and other marine life slowly started to return.

content.text1: In 2014, the Billion Oyster Project was launched in New York
content.text2: The goal: to restore one billion oysters to New York Harbor by 2035.
content.text3: Recycled oyster shells from local restaurants are used to build new reefs.
content.text4: These reefs create habitat for marine life and protect shorelines from storms.
